bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George E. Armstrong, January 15, 1953

div1.p: Hench writes about the Camp Lazear dedication. He hopes that the ceremony will help ease Cuban-American tensions surrounding the Reed-Finlay debate.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George E. Armstrong, January 15, 1953
div1.opener:
January 15, 1953
Major General George E. Armstrong
The Surgeon General
Department of the Army
Washington, D. C.
My dear General Armstrong:
div1.p:
I was so very sorry that your representative, General Streit, was prevented
by the storm from attending the dedication of Camp Lazear in Havana. It was
a disappointment to all concerned. You will remember that at my request
General Streit mentioned to you the feasibility of two rather than one wreath
being laid by your representative, one to honor the Cuban doctors, Finlay and
Delgado and one in honor of the American soldier-volunteers.

In General Streit's absence, I requested help from Ambassador Beaulac who was
most helpful. He and his aides attended the ceremony and because the repre-
sentations from you and the American Medical Association were, in my opinion,
by far the most important, Ambassador Beaulac designated two quite appropriate
men to substitute for General Streit in your behalf. Major Harold Lampner, a
member of the Medical Corps, U. S. Army, who is with some medical mission in
Cuba, unvailed Doctor Carroll's memorial plaque and placed the wreath, in your
name, substituting for General Streit, in honor of Doctors Finlay and Delgado.
Colonel Robert J. Mason, Air Attache at the Embassy, substituted for General
Streit and placed in your name a wreath in honor of the American soldier-
volunteers for the yellow fever experiments.

The ceremony was very nice indeed and was widely reported most sympathetically
in the Cuban press. General Streit's intended remarks were read in full at
the ceremony, being translated into Spanish by Doctor Nogueira and were pub-
lished essentially in full in three Cuban papers.

I realize, General Armstrong, that in these troublesome times you have much more
to do than concern yourself seriously with a historical event fifty years old.
But I am sure you realize that although the reputation of Reed and his Army
colleagues is secure throughout the world, for fifty years, especially in Cuba
and to a lesser extent in other South American countries, there has been a
strong tendency to ignore Reed and his associates, to claim that they robbed
Finlay of his glory, etc. Thus the prestige of the Army Medical Corps has
been under some fire in Cuba for many years. I do believe that the present
ceremony will do a great deal to stop the unpleasant argument, and your
representation and tributes on the occasion of the dedication were extremely
helpful and well received.

By separate post I am sending you a memorandum concerning the entire
ceremony and the diplomatic and political overtones. It may well be that
you will not have time to read it but at least it can be filed for future
use and reference if necessary and I am hoping that you can read it be-
cause I suspect that you, like I do, get some fun from turning away from
the material problems of the day and spending a little time on “matters
of the heart.”

I am enclosing a few newspaper clippings but have sent a larger collection
to General Streit. I will ask him to give to you, if you wish them, those
which are not duplicates.

General Armstrong, the two or three members of Ambassador Beaulac's staff
seemed to be quite pleased and proud to substitute for General Streit in
your behalf. They were extremely helpful because the rest of the American
delegates, although they had academic rank, were relatively unimportant to
those Cubans to whom officialdom is important and in this instance your of-
ficial representation was extremely important. Should you care or have
time to drop a little note to those who represented you, I am sure they would
appreciate it greatly. Ambassador Willard Beaulac was of course chiefly
responsible for supplying representatives for you. He unveiled the medallion
of Walter Reed. As mentioned above, Major Harold Lampner, Medical Corps, un-
veiled the medallion of Doctor Carroll and laid your wreath for Doctors
Finlay and Delgado. Colonel Robert J. Mason, Air Attache, U. S. Embassy,
laid your wreath for the American soldier-volunteers. In addition, Lt. Colonel
Vincent M. Elmore, Army Attache, represented the Walter Reed Memorial As-
sociation of which I believe you are a member and laid a wreath in honor
of Major Reed. All of these men could be addressed at the U. S. Embassy,
Havana, Cuba.

The Minister of Health of Cuba officiated at the dedication and attended
several social events in relation to the dedication and President and Mrs.
Batista gave a dinner party for a few of us American guests. President
Batista regretted the absence of your representative.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M.D. PSH:alc
